questions.text: A 65-year-old man underwent endoscopic perforator vein ligation for chronic venous insufficiency. Two weeks post-surgery, he complains of burning pain and numbness over the lateral aspect of the lower leg extending to the lateral border of the foot. Which nerve is most likely injured? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sural nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario suggests sural nerve injury following perforator vein surgery. This commonly occurs because:

  • The sural nerve closely accompanies the small saphenous vein
  • It runs in the posterolateral aspect of the leg
  • During perforator surgery, especially in the lateral calf region, the nerve is at risk
  • The sensory distribution matches the patient's symptoms (lateral leg and foot)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saphenous nerve:

 

  • Runs with the great saphenous vein on the medial aspect
  • Supplies sensation to the medial leg and foot
  • More commonly injured during great saphenous vein surgery
  • Symptoms would be on medial, not lateral aspect

 

Option B. Deep peroneal nerve:

 

  • Primarily supplies the first web space
  • Has minimal cutaneous distribution
  • Runs in the anterior compartment
  • Not typically at risk during perforator surgery

 

Option D. Tibial nerve:

 

  • Located deep in the posterior compartment
  • Mixed motor-sensory nerve
  • Would cause more extensive symptoms including motor deficits
  • Not typically injured during endoscopic procedures

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Anatomical relationship between the sural nerve and small saphenous vein is crucial during vein surgery to prevent iatrogenic injury. The sural nerve:

  1. Runs superficially in the posterolateral leg
  2. Is at risk during both open and endoscopic procedures
  3. Can cause significant post-operative morbidity if injured
  4. Should be identified and protected during perforator ligation

choices.text: Locally advanced breast cancer with axillary involvement
Early breast cancer with Cooper's ligament involvement

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with hard breast lump with breast changes. On examination, there is a hard lump of around 4x3 cm with dimpling of skin and nipple retraction, but no peau d’orange appearance. The skin changes are more prominent when the arms are raised. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted question)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Early breast cancer with Cooper’s ligament involvement 

 

Explanation:

 

The most significant finding in this case is skin puckering/dimpling that becomes more prominent with arm movement, along with nipple retraction. This is characteristic of early breast cancer with Cooper's ligament involvement.

 

When breast cancer involves Cooper's ligaments (fibrous bands that help maintain breast structure), it causes:

 

  • Tethering of the skin, leading to dimpling/puckering
  • The changes become more prominent with arm movement
  • May be associated with nipple retraction
  • Usually seen in early stages before lymphatic obstruction occurs

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory breast cancer:

 

  • Presents with peau d'orange appearance, skin erythema, and warmth
  • Caused by dermal lymphatic invasion
  • Would show more dramatic skin changes than just dimpling

 

Option B. Locally advanced breast cancer with axillary involvement:

 

  • Would typically present with peau d'orange appearance
  • Associated with fixed axillary lymphadenopathy
  • Represents a more advanced stage than simple skin dimpling

 

Option D. Ductal ectasia with periductal mastitis:

 

  • Can cause nipple retraction
  • Usually presents with nipple discharge
  • Doesn't typically cause skin dimpling/puckering

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early breast cancer involving Cooper's ligaments presents with skin dimpling/puckering that becomes more prominent with arm movement. This is different from peau d'orange appearance, which occurs in more advanced cases due to lymphatic obstruction. Understanding these differences helps in staging breast cancer and determining appropriate management strategies.

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery most commonly passes anterior to which of the following structures? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Common carotid artery

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery, after arising from the thyrocervical trunk, has a characteristic course where it ascends anterior to the medial border of scalenus anterior, then turns medially below the sixth cervical transverse process. In its course to the thyroid gland, it consistently passes anterior to the common carotid artery before reaching the lower pole of the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vertebral artery: The vertebral artery ascends through the transverse foramina of cervical vertebrae. The inferior thyroid artery does not have a consistent anterior relationship with the vertebral artery.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The relationship between the inferior thyroid artery and recurrent laryngeal nerve is highly variable. The nerve may pass anterior, posterior, or between branches of the artery. This variability is surgically significant during thyroid operations.

 

Option D. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve typically runs posterior to the common carotid artery in the carotid sheath. The inferior thyroid artery does not have a consistent anterior relationship with the vagus nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Course and relationships of the inferior thyroid artery is crucial for thyroid surgery. While its origin from the thyrocervical trunk is consistent, its most reliable anatomical relationship is passing anterior to the common carotid artery. The variable relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve is particularly important to recognize to prevent nerve injury during thyroid procedures.

questions.text: A person after neck surgery develops difficulty in rotary movements of head and inability to turn head to opposite side. Which structure is most likely to be damaged? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Accessory nerve

 

Explanation:

 

  • The accessory nerve (CN XI) innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles
  • In this case, the focus is on sternocleidomastoid dysfunction
  • Damage leads to weakness in head rotation to opposite side
  • Post-surgical injury is a common cause of accessory nerve damage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve:

 

  • Innervates only the serratus anterior muscle
  • Damage causes winging of scapula
  • Not involved in neck movements or head rotation

 

Option B. Deltoid muscle:

 

  • Responsible for shoulder abduction
  • Innervated by axillary nerve (C5, C6)
  • Not involved in neck movements

 

Option D. Sternocleidomastoid muscle:

 

  • While this is the affected muscle, the question asks about the damaged structure
  • It's the end organ, not the source of dysfunction
  • The nerve supply (CN XI) is the actual damaged structure

 

Educational Objective:

 

The accessory nerve plays a crucial role in head rotation and shoulder elevation. Its injury, often seen during neck surgeries, presents with impaired head-turning to the opposite side and shoulder droop. Recognizing this clinical scenario is essential for diagnosing and managing post-surgical complications.

questions.text: Where is the maximal blood supply for bone growth and remodeling present? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metaphysis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The metaphysis has the richest blood supply in long bones
  • It contains numerous nutrient vessels and sinusoidal capillaries
  • This rich vascularity supports active bone remodeling and growth
  • The metaphyseal region is often called the "transformation zone" due to its high metabolic activity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis:

 

  • Has relatively less vascularity compared to metaphysis
  • Blood supply mainly from epiphyseal arteries
  • Not the primary site of active bone remodeling

 

Option C. Diaphysis:

 

  • Primarily supplied by single nutrient artery
  • Has less vascularity compared to metaphysis
  • Main function is structural support rather than active growth

 

Option D. Epiphyseal plate:

 

  • While crucial for longitudinal growth, it's actually avascular
  • Relies on diffusion from epiphyseal and metaphyseal vessels
  • Cartilaginous in nature, lacking direct blood supply

 

Educational Objective:

 

The metaphysis is the most vascularized region of a long bone during growth, supporting the demands of the epiphyseal plate. This high blood supply is crucial for growth, remodeling, and repair in children and adolescents. Understanding this is important for diagnosing growth-related bone diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in taste sensation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trigeminal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

  • The trigeminal nerve (CN V) has no role in taste sensation
  • It provides general sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3rd of tongue (touch, pain, temperature)
  • While it contributes to oral sensation, it does not carry taste fibers
  • It's a mixed nerve but lacks special visceral afferent (taste) fibers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Facial nerve:

 

  • CN VII carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue via chorda tympani
  • Also carries taste from soft palate
  • Contains special visceral afferent fibers for taste

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve:

 

  • CN IX carries taste from posterior 1/3rd of tongue
  • Essential for taste perception in circumvallate papillae
  • Major contributor to bitter taste sensation

 

Option D. Vagus nerve:

 

  • CN X carries taste from epiglottis and pharynx
  • Contributes to taste sensation via its pharyngeal branches
  • Also carries taste from small area behind circumvallate papillae

 

Educational Objective:


Taste sensation is mediated by cranial nerves VII, IX, and X, while the trigeminal nerve is responsible for general somatic sensations and has no involvement in taste perception. Understanding the specific roles of cranial nerves is essential in neurological assessment and diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain for 10 days with a history of continuous fever and bradycardia after frequently consuming meals from street vendors. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Widal test

 

Explanation:

 

In cases of typhoid fever, the Widal test is a serological assay used to detect antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens (O and H antigens). While blood cultures are most effective in the early stages of the disease (first week), the Widal test becomes more reliable after the first week of illness when the antibody titers rise. In this patient, who has been experiencing symptoms for 10 days, the Widal test is the most appropriate diagnostic tool to confirm typhoid fever. It helps in identifying the immune response to the infection, thereby aiding in accurate diagnosis and timely treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood culture: Blood cultures are highly sensitive in the first week of typhoid fever but their sensitivity decreases after this period. Since the patient has been symptomatic for 10 days, the yield of blood cultures would be lower compared to serological tests like the Widal test.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures for Salmonella typhi are generally more useful in the later stages of the disease or in chronic carriers. They are not the first-line diagnostic test for acute presentations of typhoid fever.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures can be positive in the second and subsequent weeks of the illness and are useful for identifying carriers of the bacteria. However, they are less sensitive in the acute phase compared to the Widal test after the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the appropriate diagnostic tests for typhoid fever based on the duration of symptoms is crucial. Blood cultures are preferred in the early phase (first week), while serological tests like the Widal test become more reliable after the first week. Recognizing the timing of symptom onset aids in selecting the most effective diagnostic method for accurate and timely management.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent respiratory infections presents with fever, hemolytic anemia, and meningitis. There is a deficiency in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria. The likely cause can be: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haemophilus influenzae

 

Explanation:

 

Haemophilus influenzae is an encapsulated bacterium that frequently causes respiratory tract infections, meningitis, and sepsis, especially in individuals with impaired opsonization. Opsonizing antibodies, particularly IgG against the bacterial capsule, are crucial for effective phagocytosis and clearance of encapsulated organisms. A deficiency in these antibodies compromises the immune system's ability to target and eliminate Haemophilus influenzae, leading to recurrent infections characterized by fever, hemolytic anemia, and meningitis. This clinical presentation aligns with the patient's history of recurrent respiratory infections and the specific immunological deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a viral infection that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. It typically presents with symptoms like fever, fatigue, and mononucleosis-like syndrome but is not directly associated with deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies or recurrent bacterial infections.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: While Klebsiella pneumoniae is an important cause of pneumonia, especially in individuals with alcoholism, diabetes, or those who are immunocompromised, it is not specifically linked to deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria. Klebsiella infections are more related to impaired barrier defenses and other aspects of the immune response.

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Neisseria meningitidis is another encapsulated bacterium that causes meningitis and meningococcemia. However, susceptibility to Neisseria infections is more closely associated with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system (components C5-C9) rather than deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deficiencies in opsonizing antibodies against encapsulated bacteria, such as IgG against the bacterial capsule, predispose individuals to recurrent infections with organisms like Haemophilus influenzae. Recognizing the link between specific immunological defects and their associated pathogens is essential for accurate diagnosis and effective management of recurrent bacterial infections.

questions.text: A West African healthcare worker presents with fever, hemorrhagic manifestations, and acute renal failure. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebola virus

 

Explanation:

 

Ebola virus disease is prevalent in West Africa and is associated with severe hemorrhagic fever. Healthcare workers are at increased risk of exposure due to their contact with infected patients. The clinical presentation often includes fever, hemorrhagic manifestations (such as bleeding gums, petechiae, and internal bleeding), and can progress to acute renal failure. These symptoms align with the patient's presentation, making Ebola virus the most likely diagnosis in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is associated with symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It is not typically associated with hemorrhagic manifestations or acute renal failure.

 

Option B. Nipah virus: Nipah virus is transmitted from fruit bats and can cause encephalitis and respiratory symptoms. While it is severe, it is more common in South Asia and does not typically present with hemorrhagic symptoms or acute renal failure as primary features.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria, caused by Plasmodium species, presents with fever, chills, and flu-like symptoms. Severe forms can lead to complications like cerebral malaria and acute kidney injury, but hemorrhagic manifestations are not characteristic features of malaria.

 

Educational Objective:            

 

Ebola virus should be considered in patients from endemic regions, especially healthcare workers with exposure, presenting with fever and hemorrhagic symptoms. Recognizing the clinical features and understanding the transmission risks are crucial for timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis

 

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation.

 

Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells (medlar/copper penny bodies)

 

The following are the various dematiaceous species of fungi

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

 

Treatment: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions. The application of local heat is also beneficial.

 

MEDLAR/ SCLEROTIC BODIES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It does not typically present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: Pheohyphomycosis is a broad term for infections caused by dematiaceous fungi but lacks the characteristic sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with lymphocutaneous lesions but does not show the sclerotic bodies characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by:  (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Actinomyces

 

Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.

 

Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules. The most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli

 

Various clinical forms of actinomycosis include cervicofacial, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic actinomycosis.

 

Among them, actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nocardia: Incorrect, although Nocardia can also cause cutaneous infections with abscess and sinus formation, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, known primarily for causing gastrointestinal infections rather than chronic skin and soft tissue infections.

 

Option D. Tularemia: Incorrect, although it can cause ulceroglandular disease with skin ulcers and lymphadenopathy, it does not produce sulfur granules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actinomycosis, particularly its cervicofacial form, is characterized by the formation of abscesses that discharge pus containing sulfur granules. This hallmark feature helps in diagnosing the disease, which requires prolonged antibiotic therapy due to its chronic and indurative nature.

questions.text: (1-3)-B-D glucan assay cannot be used in? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive cryptococcosis

 

(1-3) - B - D glucan assay is used for diagnosis of candida infections, invasive aspergillosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

 

It is not useful in case of invasive cryptococcosis and mucor.

 

Cryptococcus species, the causative agents of invasive cryptococcosis, primarily produce glucuronoxylomannan as the major component of their capsule, not (1-3)-β-D-glucan. Therefore, the (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive aspergillosis: Aspergillus species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, and the assay is useful for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia: Pneumocystis jiroveci produces (1-3)-β-D-glucan, making the assay useful for diagnosing PCP.

 

Option D. Invasive candidiasis and candidemia: Candida species produce (1-3)-β-D-glucan, so the assay is useful for diagnosing these infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The (1-3)-β-D-glucan assay is not useful for diagnosing invasive cryptococcosis as it does not detect the major components of the Cryptococcus capsule.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test

 

The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

 

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

 

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

 

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/uL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test): This test is highly sensitive for detecting the presence of antibodies to Treponema pallidum and is used to confirm a syphilis infection but is not specific for neurosyphilis as it can be positive due to past or present infection anywhere in the body.

 

Option C. RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test): Similar to VDRL, used as a screening test for syphilis based on the detection of non-treponemal antibodies indicative of an active infection, but not specific for neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test): This is an older, highly specific test that is not commonly used today.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CSF-VDRL test, despite its low sensitivity, remains the gold standard for the diagnosis of neurosyphilis due to its high specificity when positive. It is crucial in the diagnostic process for patients with suspected syphilis infection of the central nervous system, helping guide appropriate treatment and management.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia. Caused by Coxsackie A virus. The presence of vesicular rashes in these specific locations is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In Dengue Fever, the initial rash is a transient flushing erythema of face that typically occurs shortly before or within the first 24-48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is thought to be the result of capillary dilatation. The second rash usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and it is characterized by asymptomatic maculopapular or morbilliform eruption.

 

Option C. The rash associated with the Zika virus is a combination of flat blotches (macules) and raised tiny reddish bumps like papules (not as petechiae)

 

Option D. In roseola infantum, upon rapid defervescence of the fever around days three to five, small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules will develop. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. The rash is typically nonpruritic, blanching and can persist from one to two days. Caused by HHV 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: Drug resistance is seen in which of the following STDs:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

Gonorrhea, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, has exhibited significant drug resistance over the years. Initially, penicillin was the treatment of choice for gonorrhea. However, the emergence of penicillin-resistant strains necessitated a shift to other antibiotics. Fluoroquinolones were subsequently used, but resistance to these agents also developed. Currently, third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the recommended treatment. The issue of antibiotic resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major public health concern, and ongoing surveillance and development of new treatments are crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, has not shown significant drug resistance. It remains highly sensitive to penicillin, which is still the first-line treatment for all stages of syphilis.

 

Option B. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown widespread drug resistance. It is typically treated with azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option C. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Drug resistance is not a significant issue with donovanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, the causative agent of gonorrhea, has developed resistance to multiple antibiotics, including penicillin and fluoroquinolones, making third-generation cephalosporins the current treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in urethritis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) H.ducreyi

 

Haemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid (Soft Chancre), a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy, not urethritis. Urethritis involves inflammation of the urethra, typically presenting with symptoms such as dysuria and discharge. H. ducreyi specifically causes ulcerative lesions rather than the typical inflammation and discharge associated with urethritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: While primarily known for causing trichomoniasis (a vaginitis), Trichomonas can occasionally cause urethritis, particularly in women.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, particularly among sexually transmitted bacterial infections.

 

Option C. Gonococcus (Neisseria gonorrhoeae): A well-known cause of gonococcal urethritis, presenting typically with a more severe and purulent discharge compared to NGU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

 

  1. Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhea.
  2. Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Adenovirus
    • Haemophilus vaginalis
    • Mycoplasma genitalium
    • Tricomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

choices.text: Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding scrub typhus except: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Produces NLF producing colonies in MacConkey agar

 

Causative organism – Orientia tsutsugamushi (an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium).

 

They cannot grow on cell free media. They are readily cultivated in yolk sac of developing chick embryos. They also grow on mouse fibroblast, HeLa, Hep-2, Detroit 6 and other continuous cell lines.

 

Vector - Infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus. Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Signs and Symptoms- Fever and chills, Headache, Body aches and muscle pain. Dark, scab-like region at the site of the chigger bite (also known as eschar). Mental changes, ranging from confusion to coma. Enlarged lymph nodes and rash are also seen.

 

Diagnosis of scrub typhus that includes enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), immunofluorescence assay (IFA), immunochromatographic test (ICT), Weil–Felix, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmitted by chiggers: This is true. Scrub typhus is transmitted by the larvae (chiggers) of trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Lymphadenopathy is a feature: This is true. Enlarged lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy) are a common feature of scrub typhus.

 

Option D. Man is an accidental host: This is true. Humans are accidental hosts who become infected when they come into contact with infected chiggers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot grow on cell-free media like MacConkey agar. It requires living cells for its cultivation. Scrub typhus is transmitted by chiggers and features symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite. Humans are accidental hosts for this infection.

questions.text: Vaccine can be prepared against which of the following proteins of the virus? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

The L1 protein of the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a major capsid protein and is the primary antigen used in the development of HPV vaccines. L1 proteins can self-assemble into virus-like particles (VLPs) which mimic the natural virus structure but do not contain viral DNA, making them non-infectious. These VLPs elicit a strong immune response, providing protection against HPV infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6 and E7 proteins: These are oncogenes of HPV responsible for cellular transformation and promoting oncogenesis. These proteins drive cell cycle allowing genome amplification in upper epithelial layers and degrade tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and pRb. They are not used for vaccine preparation as they do not induce a protective immune response.

 

Option C. E1 and E2 proteins: These are involved in viral replication and transcription regulation. E1 acts as an origin binding protein and ATPase-dependent helicase, while E2 regulates viral gene transcription and is associated with E1 for viral genome partitioning. They are not targets for the current vaccines.

 

Option D. DE3: This option is not relevant to HPV proteins in the context of vaccine development.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man presents with a history of dysuria and urethral discharge after having unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone

 

The symptoms with the microscopic findings which shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci suggests infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The treatment of choice for the infection is ceftriaxone.

 

Treatment of Gonorrhoea –

 

  • Third generation cephalosporins – DOC for uncomplicated gonococcal infection - both the sexual partners should be treated.
  • Ceftriaxone (250 mg given IM, single dose)
  • Cefixime (400 mg given orally, single dose)
  • If coexisting chlamydial infection – azithromycin or doxycycline added.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Erythromycin and Option B. Azithromycin are macrolides, generally used for chlamydial infections or as a co-treatment when chlamydia is suspected alongside gonorrhea.

 

Option D. Penicillin G is no longer recommended as the primary treatment for gonorrhea due to widespread resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For uncomplicated gonorrhea, especially cases presenting with urethral discharge and identified intracellular gram-negative diplococci, Ceftriaxone remains the treatment of choice. This choice reflects current guidelines that prioritize efficacy and resistance profiles in managing sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

 

  • The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.
  • Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid-fast staining technique.

 

 

Option C: The image given below is of a gram-stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii.

 

 

Option D: The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.

 

Larva currens – Strongyloides stercolaris

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercolaris: Incorrect, although Strongyloides stercolaris can cause skin symptoms (known as larva currens) due to the rapid migration of larvae, it is not the most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option B. Toxocara canis: Incorrect, this organism causes toxocariasis or visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting organs and causing systemic symptoms, rather than the localized skin manifestations seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: Incorrect, this is a human hookworm that primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms upon infection, not cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

questions.text: A patient was sputum negative for tuberculosis, but chest X-ray was suggestive of tuberculosis. Which is the next step according to RNTCP? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CBNAAT

 

CB-NAAT and Line probe assay are rapid molecular diagnostic techniques used for diagnosis of tuberculosis and also to assess resistance to isoniazid and rifampicin.

 

CB NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test) provides rapid and accurate diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and mutations responsible for rifampicin resistance. It can be used for sputum samples as well as samples from extrapulmonary sites.

 

It is mainly used for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB in key populations such as pediatric population, PLHIV and extrapulmonary TB.

 

It is done when smear is negative for TB but chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis and also in cases smear is negative and chest X-ray is not suggestive of TB but there is high index of clinical suspicion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Line probe assay: Line probe assay is another molecular diagnostic test used for detecting resistance to first-line and second-line anti-TB drugs. However, it is not the first choice for initial diagnosis following a negative sputum smear but suggestive chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Liquid culture: Liquid culture is used for confirming TB diagnosis and drug susceptibility testing. It is more time-consuming compared to molecular tests like CBNAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with negative sputum smears but chest X-ray findings suggestive of TB, CBNAAT is the recommended next diagnostic step under RNTCP guidelines.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Before examining the patient
  2. After examining the patient
  3. After touching the patient's surroundings
  4. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B and C only

 

Healthcare personnel should perform hand hygiene with soap and water when hands are visibly soiled.

 

Healthcare personnel should use an alcohol-based hand rub for the following clinical indications:

 

  • Immediately before touching a patient
  • Before performing an aseptic task (e.g., placing an indwelling device) or handling invasive medical devices
  • Before moving from work on a soiled body site to a clean body site on the same patient
  • After touching a patient or the patient’s immediate environment
  • After contact with blood, body fluids, or contaminated surfaces
  • Immediately after glove removal

 

Other Option:

 

D. Hands are visibly soiled: In this case, hand washing with soap and water is recommended rather than using a sanitizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Healthcare personnel should use hand sanitizer before and after examining a patient and after touching the patient's surroundings. However, when hands are visibly soiled, hand hygiene should be performed using soap and water instead of a sanitizer.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

choices.text: The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.
Angioinvasion is common, especially in people with hemolytic anemia.
It is a dimorphic organism, and yeast forms are seen in clinical sample.
These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages.

questions.text: A forest worker developed skin lesions over the forearm, which initially started as macules but then became nodules. Histology of the nodules shows the following findings. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The organism does not invade underlying fascia, tendon, muscle, or joints.

 

Clinical history along with sclerotic bodies on histopathology is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis and it does not commonly invade underlying tissue, tendon, or joints.

 

Chromoblastomycosis (CBM) is defined as a chronic cutaneous and subcutaneous fungal infection resulting from traumatic implantation of certain dematiaceous fungi through the skin.

 

In a typical manifestation the dermal lesions form cauliflower-like nodules. In the infected tissue, characteristic dark-colored, thick-walled, muriform cells i.e., sclerotic cells (Medlar bodies) are observed, which is a histopathological criterion for the diagnosis.

 

The most frequent aetiological agents of CBM are the following species: Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Phialophora verrucosa and Cladophialophora carrionii.

 

The etiological agent (i.e., fungal fragment) gains entrance through transcutaneous puncture wounds. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. Cases of buttock, trunk and face infection have also been reported. In more advanced stages of the disease dissemination may occur in the form of satellite lesions which arise from scratching autoinoculation and spread via the lymphatic system.

 

Treatment – Antifungal therapy with itraconazole or terbinafine. Surgical excision is the therapy of choice for small lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angioinvasion is common, especially in people with hemolytic anemia: Angioinvasion is not a common feature of chromoblastomycosis. It is more characteristic of invasive fungal infections like aspergillosis, particularly in immunocompromised patients.

 

Option C. It is a dimorphic organism, and yeast forms are seen in clinical samples: Chromoblastomycosis is caused by fungi that are not typically dimorphic. They exist in the form of sclerotic bodies in clinical samples, rather than yeast forms. Dimorphic fungi, such as Histoplasma capsulatum and Blastomyces dermatitidis, exhibit different morphologies at different temperatures (mold at 25°C and yeast at 37°C).

 

Option D. These bodies are formed by engulfment of the dead fungi by the macrophages: Sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) are not formed by macrophages engulfing dead fungi. They are thick-walled fungal cells characteristic of chromoblastomycosis, representing the fungal morphology in the infected tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by skin lesions containing sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) and does not typically invade deeper tissues such as fascia, tendons, muscles, or joints.

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: In a patient in the ICU, an infection in the central venous catheter is noted. Staining showed a gram-positive oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida

 

Candida is a genus of yeast and is the most common cause of fungal infections in humans. It is characterized by its oval shape and its mode of reproduction through budding, a form of asexual reproduction. In a healthcare setting, particularly in the ICU, Candida infections are commonly associated with the use of central venous catheters. The yeast can colonize and infect these catheters, leading to systemic infections. The identification of a gram-positive, oval-shaped organism that reproduces by budding points directly to Candida.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. E. coli: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium and does not reproduce by budding. It is typically associated with gastrointestinal infections, urinary tract infections, and other bacterial infections, but not with the description provided in this scenario.

 

Option C. Staph aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus in clusters and does not reproduce by budding. It is a common cause of various infections, including skin infections and catheter-associated infections, but its morphology and reproduction do not match the description of a budding organism.

 

Option D. Staph epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is also a gram-positive cocci and part of the normal skin flora. It is a common contaminant in blood cultures and can cause infections associated with indwelling medical devices, but it does not reproduce by budding and does not have an oval shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida is an oval-shaped yeast that reproduces by budding and is a common cause of catheter-associated infections in ICU patients.

questions.text: False about the Ebola virus is: (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transmitted by mosquito

 

Ebola viruses belong to a family of viruses termed Filoviridae. Filovirus particles form long, sometimes branched, filaments of varying shapes, as well as shorter filaments. Viral particles contain one molecule of single-stranded negative-sense RNA, enveloped in a lipid (fatty) membrane.

 

Mode of transmission - direct contact with blood or other bodily fluids, such as semen, feces, or vomit, of infected persons (or animals), including close contact with deceased EVD victims, which are highly infectious.

 

Reservoir hosts – Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir

 

Accidental Hosts – Man

 

Incubation period - 2 to 21 days.

 

Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Nosocomial transmission seen.

 

Symptoms – severe headache muscle and joint pain, weakness and fatigue, sore throat, loss of appetite, gastrointestinal symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and vomiting, Unexplained hemorrhaging, bleeding or bruising.

 

Treatment – symptomatic and supportive

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a filovirus: This is true. Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and forms filamentous viral particles containing single-stranded negative-sense RNA.

 

Option C. Bats act as reservoir: This is true. Fruit bats are considered the most likely natural reservoir hosts for the Ebola virus.

 

Option D. Nosocomial transmission seen: This is true. Nosocomial transmission, which occurs in healthcare settings, is a recognized mode of transmission for Ebola virus, often due to inadequate infection control practices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Ebola virus is a filovirus transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals, not by mosquitoes. Fruit bats are the most likely natural reservoir, and nosocomial transmission is a known route of spread.

questions.text: The Epstein-Barr virus interacts with B cells via which of the following? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CD21

 

  • The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) primarily infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor on the cell surface. CD21, also known as complement receptor 2 (CR2), is a receptor for the C3d fragment of the complement system and serves as the entry point for EBV into B cells. This interaction facilitates the virus's ability to infect and establish latency within B cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CD20: This is a protein expressed on the surface of all B cells and is involved in B cell activation and proliferation. It is not used by EBV for cell entry.

 

Option C. CD19: This is a surface protein that acts as a co-receptor in B cell receptor signaling, but it is not directly involved in EBV entry.

 

Option D. CD23: This is the low-affinity receptor for IgE and does not play a role in EBV infection of B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infects B cells by binding to the CD21 receptor, which is the primary entry point for the virus into these cells.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in the hyperacute rejection of renal transplants? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type II

 

Hyperacute graft rejection is an example of type II hypersensitivity reaction.

 

It is mediated by preformed antibodies. It is a rare event that occurs in kidney transplantation.

 

This results in rapid, severe, and often irreversible damage to the transplanted kidney, leading to graft failure. The preformed antibodies are usually directed against specific antigens on the endothelial cells of the donor organ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type IV: Incorrect, Type IV hypersensitivity is a delayed reaction mediated by T cells, not antibodies, and is not responsible for hyperacute rejection.

 

Option B. Type III: Incorrect, Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that can deposit in tissues and cause inflammation but is not the mechanism behind hyperacute rejection.

 

Option D. Type I: Incorrect, Type I hypersensitivity is an immediate allergic reaction (like asthma or anaphylaxis) mediated by IgE antibodies, which is different from the antibody-mediated attack on transplanted organs seen in hyperacute rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II hypersensitivity is crucial in the context of hyperacute rejection of renal transplants, highlighting the importance of thorough pre-transplant screening for donor-specific antibodies to avoid this rapid and destructive immune response.

questions.text:
The following are true about chancroid: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful
  4. Groove sign
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B, & C

 

Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Hemophilus ducreyi and results in painful, superficial ulcers, often with regional lymphadenopathy.

 

H. ducreyi is a small, fastidious gram-negative rod that requires an enriched growth medium cultivated in a high humidity, CO2-enriched environment. On Gram stain, long strands of organisms are seen in a pattern often referred to as a "school of fish" or "railroad track" in appearance.

 

Typically, an erythematous papule develops at the site of inoculation, which quickly becomes a pustule and subsequently develops into an extremely painful ulcer with soft irregular margins, often referred to as a "soft chancre." Multiple ulcers may be noted either as a result of multiple areas of microtrauma or as a result of direct contact between two adjacent areas resulting in "kissing ulcers." The ulcer typically has a friable base with yellow-gray exudate, which easily bleeds when abraded and varies in size, typically from 1 to 2 cm. Left untreated, the lesion spontaneously resolves within 1 to 3 months.

 

Other Option:


D. Groove sign: This is typically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and not chancroid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, is characterized by painful ulcers with a friable base that easily bleeds and has a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain. The "groove sign" is not associated with chancroid but rather with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: An 18-year-old female presents with severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. What is the Causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The clinical presentation of severe headache, high fever, papilloedema, and nuchal rigidity, combined with the Gram stain results, is highly indicative of meningococcal meningitis, caused by Neisseria meningitidis. The image from the Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing intracellular gram-negative diplococci supports this diagnosis. Neisseria meningitidis is known for appearing as gram-negative diplococci, often resembling kidney beans, and typically found within white blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate.

 

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumonia is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

 

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus and typically presents with tumbling motility in liquid media, not as diplococci.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis - Intracellular gram-negative diplococci in gram staining.

questions.text: What does ‘H’ indicate in a patient presenting with a history of EHEC O157:H7? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flagella

 

In the nomenclature of bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli (E. coli) strains like EHEC O157, the ‘H’ antigen refers to the flagellar antigen. Flagella are whip-like structures that allow bacteria to be motile. The ‘O’ antigen represents the somatic (cell wall) antigen, which is associated with the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer of the bacterial cell wall. Therefore, the ‘H’ antigen is specifically linked to flagella, which is crucial for bacterial motility and plays a role in pathogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Capsule: The capsule is a polysaccharide layer that surrounds some bacterial cells, providing protection against the host immune system. It is not related to the ‘H’ antigen.

 

Option B. Fimbriae: Fimbriae are short, hair-like structures on the bacterial surface that assist in adherence to surfaces and are not related to the ‘H’ antigen. They are different from flagella and do not contribute to motility.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharide: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is part of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria and is associated with the ‘O’ antigen, not the ‘H’ antigen. It plays a significant role in the immune response but is unrelated to bacterial motility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bacterial antigen classification, the ‘H’ antigen corresponds to flagella, which are essential for motility.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produce urease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Helicobacter pylori

 

Helicobacter pylori is well-known for its ability to produce urease, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia. This enzymatic activity is crucial for the survival of H. pylori in the acidic environment of the stomach. By producing ammonia, H. pylori can neutralize the acidity around it, creating a more hospitable environment for itself and contributing to its pathogenicity, which is associated with gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella does not produce urease and is known for causing foodborne illnesses primarily affecting the intestinal tract.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Incorrect, while some strains of E. coli can produce urease, it is not a characteristic feature, and they are primarily known for other virulence factors.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella does not produce urease and is known for causing dysentery or shigellosis through invasion and inflammation of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • asma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.
  • Match: A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.

 

2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  • Match: B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.

 

3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  • Match: C. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.

 

4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
  • Match: D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying cryptococcus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucicarmine

 

Mucicarmine staining is specifically used to identify Cryptococcus, particularly useful in highlighting the thick polysaccharide capsule that is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans, a yeast-like fungus that can cause serious infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals. The mucicarmine stain binds to the acidic polysaccharides of the fungal capsule and stains it a bright red, making it distinctly visible against a light blue background. This staining technique is especially valuable in histopathological diagnosis of cryptococcal infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giemsa stain: Primarily used for blood parasites and certain bacteria, it's not specific for fungal structures.

 

Option B. Ziehl-Nielsen stain: Used to identify acid-fast bacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, not fungi.

 

Option C. Gram staining: While it can stain a variety of bacteria, it is generally not effective for encapsulated fungi like Cryptococcus due to its poor affinity for fungal polysaccharide capsules.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An adult male patient presented with the following condition on his private parts. A gram-negative diplococci was found in the gram stain. The drug of choice for treatment is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tab Cefixime 400 mg

 

The patient presents with discharge from the penis, and the gram stain shows gram-negative diplococci. This is characteristic of an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common sexually transmitted infection that causes urethritis in males, characterized by purulent discharge and dysuria. The drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae is Cefixime 400 mg, which is effective against this bacterium due to its broad-spectrum activity against gram-negative organisms, including Neisseria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tab Azithromycin: Azithromycin is often used in combination therapy for gonorrhea to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, but it is not the primary treatment for Neisseria gonorrhoeae alone.

 

Option C. Tab Doxycycline 200 mg: Doxycycline is used primarily for chlamydial infections and is not the drug of choice for treating Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Inj. Benzathine Penicillin: Penicillin is used for treating syphilis, another sexually transmitted infection, but it is not effective against Neisseria gonorrhoeae due to the development of resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, characterized by gram-negative diplococci and purulent discharge, the recommended treatment is Cefixime 400 mg.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

 

Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect, as macrolides are effective against Mycoplasma. They work by inhibiting protein synthesis and are commonly used to treat infections caused by these bacteria.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Incorrect, tetracyclines are also effective against Mycoplasma and work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Fluoroquinolones: Incorrect, fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis, are effective against a broad range of bacteria, including Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

A-3. Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living amoeba uses pseudopodia for locomotion.

 

B-2. Balantidium coli, is a ciliated protozoan (and the largest protozoan that infects humans)

 

C-1. Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, flagellated protozoan parasite.

 

D-4.Toxoplasma gondii is a member of the phylum Apicomplexa, a diverse group of intracellular parasites that share a unique form of gliding motility. Gliding is substrate dependent and occurs without apparent changes in cell shape and in the absence of traditional locomotory organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balamuthia mandrillaris: Uses pseudopodia for movement.
  • Balantidium coli: Uses cilia for locomotion.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis: Uses flagella for movement.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Exhibits gliding motility, a substrate-dependent movement without the use of traditional locomotory organelles.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

 

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basic cycles of transmission are:

 

(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

 

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Caused by Plasmodium parasites, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily involves a human-mosquito-human cycle without bird involvement.

 

Option C. Plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, typically involves rodents and fleas in its transmission cycle; humans are incidental hosts.

 

Option D. Paragonimiasis: Caused by Paragonimus worms, involves a cycle between snails, crabs/crayfish, and mammals (including humans), but not birds or typical arthropods like mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: Which type of cartilage is the most prevalent? (NEET PG 2016 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyaline cartilage

 

Explanation:

 

Hyaline cartilage is the correct answer as it is indeed the most abundant type of cartilage in the human body. This type of cartilage is present in numerous locations throughout the body, including the larynx, trachea, ends of ribs, and covering the ends of bones where they form joints. Its extensive presence in various joints and supportive structures, its role in the growth and development of long bones (epiphyseal plates), and its ability to resist compressive forces make it notably prevalent. The characteristic homogenous, glassy appearance of hyaline cartilage, along with typically having 2-4 chondrocytes per lacuna and being covered by perichondrium (except at articular surfaces), further identifies it as the most common cartilage type.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elastic cartilage: Incorrect, as it is less common and primarily found in flexible areas such as the ear, epiglottis, and parts of the larynx.

 

Option C. Fibrocartilage: Incorrect, as it is found in specific areas that require a great deal of strength and shock absorption, such as intervertebral discs and menisci, and is not as widespread as hyaline cartilage.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as hyaline cartilage is extensively documented as the most prevalent type of cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyaline cartilage is the most abundant type of cartilage found in the body, known for its widespread presence in various supportive and articulatory structures.

questions.text: During climbing the staircase, a person suddenly fell & a sharp object hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder & he is having difficulty in turning his head. What structure is most likely to be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal accessory nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) innervates both the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. The trapezius muscle is responsible for the elevation or shrugging of the shoulder, while the sternocleidomastoid muscle is responsible for turning the head. Injury to the spinal accessory nerve results in an inability to perform these actions, which matches the patient's symptoms of being unable to shrug/elevate the shoulder and having difficulty turning the head. Therefore, the most likely structure damaged in this case is the spinal accessory nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is responsible for the protraction and upward rotation of the scapula. Damage to this nerve causes winging of the scapula, not an inability to shrug the shoulder or turn the head.

 

Option C. Sternocleidomastoid: While the sternocleidomastoid muscle is indeed involved in turning the head, its dysfunction alone would not explain the inability to shrug the shoulder. The issue lies with the nerve that innervates both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option D. Deltoid: This muscle is innervated by the axillary nerve and is responsible for shoulder abduction. Damage to the deltoid or axillary nerve would cause difficulty in shoulder abduction, not in shrugging the shoulder or turning the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal accessory nerve (11th cranial nerve) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles, which are essential for shrugging the shoulder and turning the head, respectively.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fornix

 

  • The image given shows a midsagittal section of the brain.
  • The structure marked is the Fornix.
  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter located in the medial surface of the brain, just below the corpus callosum.
  • The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and it is the hippocampus's largest single pathway, connecting it to various subcortical structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: It is a small endocrine gland located in a midsagittal section, seen as a small structure located posterior to the third ventricle in the midline, projecting from the diencephalon. Its main hormone, melatonin, plays a critical role in the regulation of circadian rhythms, influencing sleep-wake cycles.

 

Option B. Falx cerebri: It is a dural fold that descends vertically in the longitudinal fissure, which divides the cerebral hemispheres. In a midsagittal view, it appears as a thin membrane running vertically between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. The falx cerebri attaches anteriorly to the crista galli of the ethmoid bone and posteriorly to the internal occipital protuberance.

 

Option D. Pituitary gland: It is often referred to as the "master gland", is an endocrine gland responsible for producing several critical hormones that regulate growth, blood pressure, and other functions. In the midsagittal view, the pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, hanging down from a stalk (infundibulum) from the hypothalamus. This gland rests within a depression in the sphenoid bone called the sella turcica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers that acts as a major output tract from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies and then onto the thalamus. In the midsagittal section, the fornix is seen as an arching structure that lies inferior to the corpus callosum, the massive fiber tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres. The body of the fornix travels anteriorly and inferiorly, eventually dividing into left and right columns which curve downward in front of the thalamus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a positive Trendelenburg test. Identify the nerve injured: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior gluteal nerve

 

  • Function: It innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae. These muscles are significant abductors of the hip and play a critical role in pelvis stabilization during walking.
  • Clinical Significance: If this nerve were injured and the patient stood on the left leg, the right side of the pelvis would drop due to the inability to stabilize the pelvis on the stance leg. However, if the Trendelenburg test was positive on the right side, it wouldn't correlate with the left superior gluteal nerve injury.
